What We Offer   Target Audience     Schedule Topics   Application & Enrollment Process   Portfolio Download   Start the Dialogue     Your Return on Investment Experience Stern   Our Faculty   The Data   Testimonials     Frequently Asked Questions   Contact Us             Home / Programs & Admissions / Executive Education / Short Courses / Schedule / Innovation Week                        Share / Print                Print      Email      Share       Like                                              Innovation Week                            Description                      Faculty                      Participant Demographic                      Daily Agenda                      Apply                             Date  June 15-16 and June 18-19, 2015   Location  NYU Campus, Greenwich Village   Cost  $6,200 (Accommodation not included)        “Innovation Week” is a bundled course offering of both the Disruptive Leadership: Fostering a Culture of Game-Changing Innovation course on Monday, June 15 and Tuesday, June 16, as well as the Strategic Innovation: Tapping the Power of the Crowd course on Thursday, June 18 and Friday, June 19 for a total discounted price of 15%.    Immerse yourself in a week on innovation. Uncover and build a framework for fostering a culture of game-changing innovation that generates new ideas and executes new solutions. It is an essential skill for any business leader, from a small start-up to a global corporation, with the desire to transform organizational processes and behaviors, and ask, “Why hadn’t we ever thought about our business and culture this way before?”    At the same time, organizations are turning to crowdsourcing platforms to source better information, new ideas and insights, more diverse opinions and to distribute and share work and do tasks. Few have mastered the art of tapping into “the crowd” to generate real value even though the crowd has proven to be an exceptionally fruitful source of innovation. In the second part of “Innovation WeeK,” work with leadership faculty on identifying and honing the right problem for crowdsourcing, building and sustaining communities of contributors, generating implementable and actionable innovations, recognizing the value of external ideas, and transforming organizations to overcome the “Not Invented Here” syndrome.    June 15-16, 2015   Disruptive Leadership: Fostering a Culture of Game-Changing Innovation - Course Details    June 18-19, 2015   Strategic Innovation: Tapping the Power of the Crowd - Course Details    Program Benefits:  Drill down into the innovation mindset and develop individual potential products and solutions, while enhancing your network of innovation peers.    *Please note that the program is subject to be cancelled under unforeseeable circumstances.               Luke Williams  Luke Williams joined New York University Stern School of Business in September 2012 as Executive Director of the Berkley Center for Entrepreneurship & Innovation and Clinical Associate Professor of Marketing and Entrepreneurship. He was previously an adjunct professor. Professor Williams is also a Fellow at frog design.    Professor Williams is a leading consultant, educator and speaker specializing in disruptive innovation. He is the author of Disrupt: Think the Unthinkable to Spark Transformation in Your Business. For more than a decade, he has worked internationally with industry leaders such as American Express, GE, Sony, Crocs, Virgin, Disney and Hewlett-Packard to develop new products, services and brands.    Professor Williams has been invited to speak worldwide, and his views have been featured in Bloomberg Businessweek and Fast Company and on National Public Radio (NPR).    Read his full bio .      Anat Lechner  Anat Lechner is a Clinical Associate Professor of Management and Organizations at NYU Stern School of Business. Professor Lechner's research focuses on how organizations can best structure to develop innovation capabilities and outcomes. Her current work looks at the complexities of managing high performance cross-functional teams, and the ways by which physical workplace environments enable organization members to cope with uncertainty, change and the demand for increased innovativeness.    Read her full bio.      Beth Noveck  Beth Simone Noveck directs The Governance Lab ( www.thegovlab.org ) and its MacArthur Research Network on Opening Governance. Funded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation and Google.org, the GovLab strives to improve people’s lives by changing how we govern.    The Jacob K. Javits Visiting Professor at New York University’s Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service and a visiting professor at the MIT Media Lab, Beth is a professor of law at New York Law School. She served in the White House as the first United States Deputy Chief Technology Officer and director of the White House Open Government Initiative (2009-2011). UK Prime Minister David Cameron appointed her senior advisor for Open Government, and she served on the Obama-Biden transition team. Among projects she's designed or collaborated on are Unchat, The Do Tank, Peer To Patent, Data.gov, Challenge.gov and the Gov Lab's Living Labs (livinglabs.thegovlab.org) and training platform (thegovlabacademy.org).    A graduate of Harvard University and Yale Law School, she serves on the Global Commission on Internet Governance and chairs the ICANN Strategy Panel on Multi-Stakeholder Innovation.    Read her full bio .      Natalina Levina  Natalia Levina is an Associate Professor at New York University Stern School of Business. Professor Levina teaches courses on Global Sourcing and Open Innovation as well as Information Systems and Organizations Doctoral Seminar.    Professor Levina has been with NYU Stern for over than ten years. Prof. Levina's main research interest is in understanding how people span organizational, professional, cultural and other boundaries in the process of building and using new technology. She uses qualitative and quantitative methods and a range of social and organizational theories in her work. She currently studies boundary spanning in the context of open innovation, crowdsourcing, and offshoring of professional services.    Professor Levina received her B.A. in Computer Science and Mathematics and M.A.in Mathematics from Boston University. She received her Doctor of Philosophy in Information Technology from Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management.    Read her full bio .               Who Should Attend:       Individuals with high potential for leadership    Individuals who are managing other people or teams    Individuals with significant leadership responsibilities    Anyone interested in fostering a broad-based culture of innovation    Managers in R&D, marketing, and technology functions    Corporate and organizational decision makers who want to engage in participatory decision making and who want to leverage the wisdom of the crowd and/or their organization    Business, government and non-profit leaders                   Program Session Details   Day 1 - Disruptive Leadership: Fostering a Culture of Game-Changing Innovation     Session 1   Ideas as Recipes for Generating New Value and Wealth       Introduction to understanding the value of ideas and innovation    Applying disruptive leadership to innovation challenges     Session 2   Provoking Organizational Processes and Behaviors with Disruptive Hypotheses       Identifying the assumptions and conventions that influence the way producers and consumers think about your business    How to break through the boundaries of your industry situation    Generating deliberately unreasonable "what if" questions    Networking Reception     Day 2 - Disruptive Leadership: Fostering a Culture of Game-Changing Innovation     Session 3   Building and Leading Disruptive Teams       From command and control to connect and collaborate    The importance of innovation leadership    Building and leading disruptive teams     Session 4   Pitching Disruptive Ideas to the Organization and External Stakeholders       Establishing the inadequacy of the status quo    Delivering unexpected insights and opportunities to foster curiosity    Building belief in the value an idea delivers    Program Conclusion and Evaluation     Day 3 - Strategic Innovation: Tapping the Power of the Crowd     Session 1   Understanding Crowdsourcing’s Potential     Session 2   Crowdsourcing for Innovation: Identifying Suitable Problems     Session 3   Crafting an Effective Open Innovation Process: Honing and Framing the Problem     Session 4   Crowdsourcing and Governance    Networking Reception     Day 4 - Strategic Innovation: Tapping the Power of the Crowd     Session 5   Attracting and Motivating the Crowd     Session 6   Building a Collaborative Innovation Community     Session 7   Crafting an Effective Open Innovation Process: Designing the Process and Choosing the Platform     Session 8   The Future of Crowdsourcing: New Frontiers    Networking Reception              Submit an application by clicking the below icon. How can I access demographic information?  8 How can I access my previously submitted evaluations?  9 How can I review individual evaluation responses?          I have a Kerberos ID and Password - How can I access my New Innovations account?     Users with an NYU account can login to New Innovation by visiting the  NYU New Innovations Login Portal  ( https://www.new-innov.com/nyu/ ) and entering their Kerberos ID and password.    After clicking the "Log In with Kerberos ID/ NetID" button, you'll see the following screen to enter your Kerberos ID and password:                   If your account requires a password reset, please visit the Kerberos Password Reset page:  https://apps.nyumc.org/PasswordReset/lookup.html             How can I access New Innovations, if I don't have a Kerberos ID?     Non-NYU users can access their New Innovations account by visiting the direct New Innovations login portal ( https://www.new-innov.com/login/ ) and entering their New Innovations client-specific username and password.                In order to obtain your NI username and password, please feel free to contact #NewInnovationsSupport@nyumc.org    Why has my Personnel Information query been denied? Admin users can only access Personnel Data for students and faculty members associated with their specific program.  If an Educator has been assigned on the Faculty Schedule, but has not been formally added to your program, their account will not be available for viewing/editing.                                                      In order to obtain login credentials, please feel free to contact  #NewInnovationsSupport@nyumc.org        I have more than one program associated with my account - How can I toggle between departments?     Login to your New Innovations account and then select Change Department  from the top, horizontal navigation bar.         Select your preferred department:           Is there a "Not Applicable" option for erroneously assigned evaluations?  In the event that you have been matched as an evaluator for a Subject/User whom you have not had sufficient enough opportunity to properly assess--you can opt to submit the pending evaluation as NET - Not Enough Time     Once you have logged-in to NI, click the pending evaluations link on your dashboard   Then, check the evaluations to be submitted as NET   In the example below, only the evaluation for "Subject Name 2" will be submitted as NET                 How do I change the photo in a user's Personnel Data file?     Admin users can modify the photo field of an account associated with their program by selecting the user from the Personnel Data screen and clicking on " CHANGE PHOTO ":               Where has my Personnel Data View gone? How can I access demographic information?     Admin users who have the capability to add new accounts within NI, might see the screen below:             In order to access the default demographic folder view, please click  View Editor         How can I access my previously submitted evaluations?     Evaluators can review old evaluations by clicking on Main-->Evaluations-->Completed Evaluations           How can I review individual evaluation responses?     Admin users can review evaluation submissions by clicking on Main-->Evaluations-->Evaluation Status List                        Comments                           NYULMC Home  |  Contact Us  |  For Faculty & Staff  |  Careers  |  Make a Gift   |  Policies & Disclaimers  |  Academic Departments                Sign in | Report Abuse | Print Page | Powered By Google Sites
